answer_html: By applying Euler’s method with a step size of \(\Delta t = 0.1\), our next point would be at the value \(y(0.1) = 1.1\), which is answer \({\color{blue}\text{(E)}}\).
answer_latex:
By applying \textbf{Euler's method} with a step size of
$\Delta t = 0.1$, our next point would be at the value
$y(0.1) = 1.1$,
which is answer ${\color{blue}\text{(E)}}$.
hints_html: Euler’s method is an iterative method whereby we start with the initial value, plug it into our differential equation to find the slope, then use the slope of this tangent line to find the next point on the curve that is \(\Delta t\) units away.
hints_latex:
\textbf{Euler's method} is an \emph{iterative} method whereby we start
with the initial value, plug it into our differential equation to find
the slope, then use the slope of this tangent line to find the next
point on the curve that is $\Delta t$ units away.
hints_raw: '''Euler's method''' is an ''iterative'' method whereby we start with the initial value, plug it into our differential equation to find the slope, then use the slope of this tangent line to find the next point on the curve that is <math> \Delta t </math> units away.
question: A 03
sols_html:
We start at the point \((0,1)\), where the slope of the tangent line at this point is

\(\frac{dy}{dx} = 2 - y^2 = 2 - [y(0)]^{2} = 2-1 = 1\)

By applying Euler’s method with a step size of \(\Delta t = 0.1\), our next point would be at the value \(y(0.1) = y(0) + \left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{ x=0 }(0.1 - 0) = 1 + 0.1 = 1.1\), which is answer \({\color{blue}\text{(E)}}\).
sols_latex:
We start at the point $(0,1)$, where the slope of the tangent line at
this point is

$\frac{dy}{dx} = 2 - y^2 = 2 - [y(0)]^{2} = 2-1 = 1$

By applying \textbf{Euler's method} with a step size of
$\Delta t = 0.1$, our next point would be at the value
$y(0.1) = y(0) + \left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{ x=0 }(0.1 - 0) = 1 + 0.1 = 1.1$,
which is answer ${\color{blue}\text{(E)}}$.
sols_raw:
We start at the point <math> (0,1) </math>, where the slope of the tangent line at this point is

<math> \frac{dy}{dx} = 2 - y^2 = 2 - [y(0)]^{2} = 2-1 = 1 </math>


By applying '''Euler's method''' with a step size of <math> \Delta t = 0.1 </math>, our next point would be at the value <math> y(0.1) = y(0) + \left.\frac{dy}{dx}\right|_{ x=0 }(0.1 - 0) = 1 + 0.1 = 1.1 </math>, which is answer <math>{\color{blue} \text{(E)}}</math>.
statement_html:
Consider the differential equation and initial condition

\(\frac{dy}{dt} = 2 - y^2,\quad y(0) = 1\)

Use Euler’s method with one step of size \(\Delta t = 0.1\) to approximate the value of the solution at time \(t = 0.1\)

(a) \(y(0.1) = 2\)

(b) \(y(0.1) = 2.1\)

(c) \(y(0.1) = 2.2\)

(d) \(y(0.1) = 1.2\)

(e) \(y(0.1) = 1.1\)
statement_latex:
Consider the differential equation and initial condition

$\frac{dy}{dt} = 2 - y^2,\quad y(0) = 1$

Use Euler's method with one step of size $\Delta t = 0.1$ to approximate
the value of the solution at time $t = 0.1$

(a) $y(0.1) = 2$

(b) $y(0.1) = 2.1$

(c) $y(0.1) = 2.2$

(d) $y(0.1) = 1.2$

(e) $y(0.1) = 1.1$
statement_raw:
Consider the differential equation and initial condition

<math>\frac{dy}{dt} = 2 - y^2,\quad y(0) = 1</math>

Use Euler's method with one step of size <math>\Delta t = 0.1</math> to approximate the value of the solution at time <math>t = 0.1</math>

(a) <math> y(0.1) = 2 </math>

(b) <math> y(0.1) = 2.1 </math>

(c) <math> y(0.1) = 2.2</math>

(d) <math> y(0.1) = 1.2</math>

(e) <math> y(0.1) = 1.1</math>
